title: Theories Explaining the Gender Gap
text:
Social Identity Theory (SIT) helps explain how the under-representation of women in STEM is influenced by their perceived membership in social groups just like the group: Women in STEM; and this will significantly influence their behaviors (Hogg 2016). According to SIT, when women perceive STEM as a male-dominated domain, they are less likely to pursue or persist in these fields. This is compounded by social identity threats that reduce self-esteem and motivation (Tajfel 1986).



Kim, Sinatra, and Seyranian (2018) found that societal beliefs about women’s roles in STEM reduce their interest and self-identification with STEM fields.
Cheryan and Plaut (2010) demonstrated that women feel less similar to the typical academic prototype in fields like computer science, reducing their interest in pursuing these disciplines.




Highlight diverse role models: emphase that STEM is for everyone can significantly improve women’s engagement with these fields.

title: Theories Explaining the Gender Gap
text:
Key Research

Piatek-Jimenez, Cribbs, and Gill (2018) revealed that traits like competitiveness and risk-taking are seen as masculine and discourage women from considering STEM careers.
Dicke, Safavian, and Eccles (2019) found that traditional gender role beliefs influence educational attainment and career aspirations, particularly in STEM fields.

title: Theories Explaining the Gender Gap
text:
Actionable Change:
More diverse media representation can help women feel that they can do well in STEM regardless of societal gender expectations.

title: Gender Disproportion in STEM: Under-Represented Women Population
text:
The underrepresentation of women in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) fields remains a deeply ingrained issue with far-reaching consequences. Despite progress in some areas, the gender imbalance is stark: women represent only 28.2% of the STEM workforce, a significant contrast to their 47.3% representation in non-STEM sectors. Even more concerning is the underrepresentation of women in leadership roles in STEM, with women holding just over 10% of these positions (Pal, Piaget, and Zahidi 2024), seeTable 1. As technology and innovation continue to shape our future, closing this gender gap is crucial not only for fairness but also for creating a diverse and comprehensive landscape that better addresses global challenges.




Table 1: This bar plot highlights the gender disparity between women in STEM and non-STEM sectors. Women make up 28.2% of the STEM workforce, compared to 47.3% in non-STEM roles. In leadership positions, women hold only 10% of STEM roles, emphasizing the ongoing gender gap. Source (Pal, Piaget, and Zahidi 2024)










While countries like Iceland, Finland, and Norway have made strides in promoting gender equality in many sectors, STEM remains one of the most stubborn areas for gender equity. This issue limits career opportunities for women, undermining personal development, economic independence, and the overall growth of these fields (Education n.d.). This issue has been ongoing for decades and continues to persist, with some progress made in recent years, but the gap remains substantial.

title: Gender Disproportion in STEM: Under-Represented Women Population
text:
Raising Awareness and Encouraging Change
Research underscores the significant barriers women face in STEM, not just in terms of access to opportunities but also in terms of ongoing systemic challenges (Education n.d.). Women in these fields encounter unconscious bias, gendered stereotypes, and the threat of social exclusion. As a result, women are nearly 20% more likely to leave STEM careers than their male counterparts, as demonstrated in Table 2. These challenges are even more pronounced in high-demand fields such as artificial intelligence (AI), programming, and cybersecurity, where women continue to face substantial barriers (Pal, Piaget, and Zahidi 2024).

section: Your Effort by Browsing This Website!
text:
Your Effort by Browsing This Website!
This website was created to: - Raise awareness about the under-representation of women in STEM fields. - Encourage collective action toward closing the gender gap in STEM. - Provide insights into the underlying causes of gender disparity in STEM. - Advocate for those in positions of power over STEM fields to take action and shape the future of STEM with greater gender equality.
By everyone understanding why the gender disparity in STEM exists and recognizing the current state of the situation, we can all play a part in addressing the issue. It’s not just about one group or individual making changes; it’s about fostering a collective effort!

Let’s work together to ensure that women in STEM not only have equal access to opportunities but also the encouragement, resources, and role models they need to succeed!

title: About the Issue
text:
There is a significant gender disparity in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) fields, with women underrepresented in both academic and professional settings. This gender gap continues to persist despite various efforts to improve diversity and inclusion in these sectors.
The Global Gender Gap Report (Pal, Piaget, and Zahidi 2024) highlights the persistent under-representation of women in STEM fields.

Women face higher dropout rates and fewer opportunities.
Interest in STEM careers among women is often lower compared to men, influenced by systemic barriers.

To explore why and how this gender disparity occurs further through theories, click here:

Click here to learn more about theoretical reason behind the issue!



Fewer than 30% of STEM professionals globally are women. While representation of women is relatively stronger in fields like biology, it is drastically lower in areas including:

Computer Science
Physics
Engineering

Issues also involve support, experience, and engagement challenges fro woman in STEM, such as lack of mentorship, pervasive stereotypes, and biased educational practices, which make it significantly harder for women to succeed in STEM fields (Education n.d.).

title: About the Issue
text:
Who is Involved:

Women in STEM: Women are directly impacted by barriers to entry, unequal opportunities, and challenges to career advancement.
Educational Institutions: Universities and schools play a crucial role in attracting women into STEM disciplines and providing the support needed to ensure greater future success. It’s essential to create environments where hiring practices are free from bias.
Organizations and Employers: Companies in STEM-related industries have a significant responsibility to foster an inclusive workplace, ensuring equal opportunities and providing support for women to thrive.

For those involved in this issue (not limited to the groups mentioned above), if you have a current story to share that can inspire future change-makers, you’re welcome to share your story with everyone:

Click here to share your story in STEM!

title: About the Issue
text:
Why Important? Towards the Future
Addressing gender disparity in STEM is important not only for fairness and equality but also for the advancement of knowledge and innovation in our society. Diversity brings a variety of perspectives, leading to more solutions, better decision-making, and advancements that benefit everyone, regardless of gender.

title: Share Your Story
text:
You Can Share

General Personal Experiences: Have you faced challenges or overcome obstacles in your journey through STEM (study or working)? Share your strategies to overcome them for others!
Concerns: What is your current concern in your STEM journey? Encountered barriers, such as bias, stereotypes, or lack of support? There will definitely be people who resonate with you!
Success Stories: It’s always good to hear positive stories! What did it mean to you? How did it shape your future decisions and confidence in STEM?
Mentorship: Have you experienced a mentor who guided you? Or are you a mentor who has helped others navigate their path in STEM? Share your experience for others!
